q.a: usually what seems to work best (for me) is to make sure you fully write the song first, before really recording it. know exactly how it goes, and for exactly how long. Doing a full recording/arrangement of a song is crazy enough, and if you don't know how the song goes you'll surely crumble. unless you are doing the type of arrangement that can be delivered in its final form in real time. It's like building a house. you have to know the specific plans of the house before building it, unless you have technology so advanced that the house can be built instantly, in which case yes you could definitely improvise the house

q.a: the trick is, instead of finding a sound for each place in the song, find a place in the song for each sound. DON'T put it if it doesn't fit, but just keep searching from place to place until it really fits. doesn't count if it doesn't fit. with this technique you have to keep searching until it really fits, but it does still also have to go somewhere. but NOT anywhere, has to fit. but it has to go somewhere. i hope i have explained that properly. Also, you still have to do the song's core with fewer and more reliable basic instruments, but the decorations should be done on a 'what then when' basis rather than a 'when then what' basis. this is for production. writing usually goes the other way (when-what)

q.q: your dedication to getting things done honestly amazes me. martin molin often talks about delayed gratification; he's been working on an extremely complex marble machine for the past 3 and a half years and he's been talking about how it's hard to stay motivated when you're working on something for so long and you don't get to see the finished product until the end. but even he does weekly build logs, which is a regular form of creative output. You, on the other hand, spent almost a year working exclusively on HotEWIG with no output whatsoever. and you're doing something similar right now, except you don't even really seem to have a solid, set end goal this time.
there's no one big project you'll get to release at the end of this that will make you feel satisfied like all of that hard work culminated into this one big thing.

q.a: if you've never done any show, then you really won't have any idea of how it's going to go until you do it
q.q: hi bill, ive been part of this show where me and someone else read stuff and try to make comedy with it. weve been morphing the format over time to tailor it to a specific imaginary viewership as well as trying to "emulate what works on youtube" and lately magic has felt a little bit lacking. the big dilemma is, how much should we prepare vs how much should we not prepare to have a good consistent show. it feels like if its based on improv, 100% not prepared is the way to go, just choose something to read and jump in live. its really tough finding that balance between what should be prepared or "practiced" or "planned", but the more i think about it the more it feels like we need to jump in blind if we really mean this to be a show that relies on improv for the fun. do you have any thoughts on this preparation/pre-planning/practiced dynamic?
